intro: Carex paradoxa subsp. pseudoparadoxa, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sedges, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered inflorescences. It typically grows in wet or moist environments such as marshes, swamps, and along stream banks. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
